content.webTitle: Stoke’s Jack Butland shows Steve McClaren what Newcastle are missing

fields.headline: Stoke’s Jack Butland shows Steve McClaren what Newcastle are missing
fields.bodyText: Ruud Gullit knows precisely what Steve McClaren is going through. During his own days in charge at Newcastle United the Dutchman became so vexed he is said to have asked a Catholic priest to bless the pitch before sprinkling holy water around the home dressing room. “Did Ruud really do that?” said McClaren at the end of yet another frustrating match when once again the scoreline failed to reflect a much improved performance from his team. A few hours later Gullit delivered words of sympathy and encouragement from a seat in the BBC Match of the Day studio. Indeed the consensus – disputed by a slightly miffed Mark Hughes – was that Jack Butland’s excellence in Stoke City’s goal had denied Newcastle what would have been only their second Premier League win of the season. They remain stuck in the relegation zone with Saturday’s trip to Bournemouth assuming an importance unimaginable in August, when even McClaren underestimated the scale of the reconstruction job ahead. Like Hughes, the former England coach is in the process of converting a direct side into one capable of controlling games with passing football. The difference is that Stoke already possessed the steely spine that serves as an ideal framework within which new players and a fresh philosophy could flourish. If Newcastle’s board had agreed to grant Yohan Cabaye’s wish and buy the team’s old midfield calibrator back from Paris Saint-Germain last summer along with another centre-half and an extra striker, McClaren would surely not be describing the Bournemouth trip as “very important.” He approaches it with Tim Krul and Karl Darlow, his first- and second-choice goalkeepers, suffering from knee and ankle injuries respectively and Rob Elliot, the third in line, struggling badly with a groin problem. Does Newcastle’s manager gamble on throwing the 18-year-old Freddie Woodman in at the deep end or attempt to make an emergency loan signing? Should Manchester United’s out-of-favour Víctor Valdés – who is believed to be the preferred option – arrive, McClaren can only trust he replicates Butland’s highly convincing impression of a magnetic force field. “I can’t repeat what Steve said to me at the end,” joked the Stoke goalkeeper, who had a stint playing for Newcastle’s manager last season, making six appearances while on loan at Derby County during the autumn. Then Butland turned his attentions to Joe Hart – the man who has restricted him to two England caps. This time his message was serious. “My ambition is to be England’s No1 keeper, 100%,” he said. “I have a really good relationship with Joe but I want to play for England at his expense. I want to play in the European Championships next summer.” Man of the match Jack Butland (Stoke City)
